instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
Hi, this board tries to start, goes to .74A a couple seconds and goes down to .54A and then it shuts down and repeat the same over and over again. I checked the board for corrosion and found corrosion on <RESISTOR>R6102</RESISTOR>, I cleaned it on the ultrasonic and had to change <RESISTOR>R6102</RESISTOR> after doing that, now it is having the same behavior.
 What should I check first?

Happy New Year!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
Check ALL SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean/remove J6100.
Reball SMC, as usual for corroded boards.

Does it start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
I reballed SMC, j6100 is clean and SPI Bus Series resistors have correct values and look OK. Still not working properly. On PIN 1 <RESISTOR>R6115</RESISTOR> getting a pulse when turning on, but only a pulse of around 1v and then goes back to 0v.
I was thinking about reprograming BIOS, I have a TL866Plus but can´t read the BIOS on that programmer or maybe I am doing something the wrong way...  Does that bios need different programming ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message: Use new chip for <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message: I got a <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> from donor, but still can´t read it on my TL866, is it. different from other bios chips? I put other bios and can read them with no problem, double checked the soldering pads and they were ok. Don´t know what to do anymore...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
Your programmer may not recognize the chip properly.
Manually choose a compatibloe chip (8MB) and try to read/write it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
When trying to start it in SMC bypass mode it does the same, but the backlights turns on for a couple seconds and then turns back off but this time doesnt loop, it stays off. 

update: I was turning it on without the hard drive, with the hard drive it turns on, get to the login screen for around 10 seconds and shuts down... Changed the cpu thermal paste, same behavior...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
Can you access boot menu?
Still turns off then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message: I can but still shuts down...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
If turns of in boot menu, then is no macOS related issue.

Does this with original BIOS?
Clean ME region, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message: It turns off in the boot menu, it shows me the hard drive to boot of around 10 seconds, the same that in login screen and it shuts down, the BIOS is the original and the problem is that I cant read the BIOS chip in my programmer...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
Ok, so I couldn´t reprogram the BIOS because I think it´s an EEPROM and don´t have programmer for that. but found out that it only starts in smc bypass mode, it loads to the log in screen and turns off 10 seconds later. Does the backlight can make the board to shut down? It is wierd that only in smc bypass mode I get  backlight and image for a couple seconds, but trying to boot it normally it doesn´t turn on the backlight... what could make the board to shutdown? I checked temperature and current sensors and everything seems to be ok.

A little detail: When it turns on, it starts at 600-700ma then it goes down to 360ma and starts to go up by 10ma until it gets to  390ma that´s the point where it turns off. When it turns off <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> goes as low as around 7.8v. I dont think that is normal behavior...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message: Did you check charging circuit current paths sensing and fuse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> .74A then .54A then OFF
threads.message:
Shouldn't be a sensor issue, if still turns off in SMC bypass.
Looks like a problem near <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, causing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> drop.
Inspect that area, resolder and check traces.
Try changing <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
Test with fake charger, or lab PSU.
